Bruce Williamstheen, more commonly known as Bruce Springsteen, was born on September 23, 1949, in Freehold Township, New Jersey, United States. He is an acclaimed American singer-songwriter, musician, and actor, often referred to as the "Boss" by his fans. His career has spanned over four decades, and his music has left an indelible mark on American popular culture.

Springsteen began his musical journey at an early age, inspired by the likes of Bob Dylan, The Beatles, and the traditional American music of his New Jersey upbringing. In 1964, he joined his first band, The Castiles, and later formed the Asbury Park Stand-Ins, a garage rock group.

In 1971, Springsteen's career took off when he joined the E Street Band, a group of talented musicians who would become his collaborators and friends for nearly five decades. The E Street Band's first album, "Greetings from Asbury Park, N.J.," was released in 1973, and their second album, "The Wild, the Innocent & the E Street Shuffle," released in 1973, established Springsteen's signature sound, a mix of rock 'n' roll, folk, and blue-collar ballads.
